title: Open PHACTS: A Data Platform for Drug Discovery

author: Paul Groth, Department of Computer Science, Faculty of Sciences, Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU)

segmentation: So I'm going to try to try to address all of you today with this this talk Ann.

What's really nice is that we've already seen in the panel before, and in the last talk a number of things that will address here really about public private partnerships about the variety of big data.
So dealing with variety about business models, how we might do business models and service models around big data, and in this particular thing will do.
Actually what I would call a success story.
For European big data platforms and what I'll talk today about is this project called Open Fax and the Open Fax platform.
So we'll talk a little bit about why what we're doing.
The actual thing we have that's available, how people are using it in terms of apps that are out there are used in so far, and what we're doing about this notion of the future.
How do we sustain this platform?
And how do we create this kind of ecosystem where you can drive innovation in this particular space?
So what space are we talking about?
We're really talking about drug discovery, and this project comes out of a, I think, a really unique funding scheme that is really something that's only available in Europe.
This is called the Innovative Medicines Initiative, and this is where a large group of large pharmaceutical companies got together with the European Union to put together.
Kind of a large pot of money to facilitate pre competitive.
Initiatives around drug discovery around making better drugs and so open fax is one of these projects.
It has tons of partners.
The most kind of ones I want to pick out here are major pharmaceutical companies, so we have Pfizer and GSK and Astra Zeneca.
Merck, Lilly all the all the companies that you know from the back of your medicine.
If you take those but also major data providers within Europe.
So this is the Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics or EBI.
And so the idea here is that these companies and these public organizations, along with academics, come together to try to address a pre competitive problem.
So what's the problem?
That open fax addresses?
It's this data integration problem, so inside each pharma company today they have a data integration procedure.
They go out and take all this public data that's made by scientists in different facilities and try to integrate that an they actually.
This is something that every pharma company does right so they have big ETL systems that they have in house and they do this and then they do this inside each of these different companies.
And this is not a core competency of those companies.
They don't see themselves as data integration companies right there about drug discovery about finding that next big drug.
So this is someplace where cooperation across these companies would help.

But also it would help the public right, because if you go to an academic researcher in this space, they actually don't have access to all this data coming from multiple sources in an integrated fashion because they don't have these huge data integration systems, they can't afford that.
So the idea behind open fax is too.
Create a platform to enable data integration of public domain drug discovery data.
And here what we're talking about are things like chemistry, data biology, protein data, and I'll tell a little bit about the data sources we're talking about in just a second.
So we've developed this platform and.
We took a also a business question driven approach to develop this platform.

We actually got all the representatives from the pharma company in the room and ask them to write down their top business questions and then rank them and you can actually go get an Open Access paper.
It will list all those.
Questions for you and their questions like find me aloxi reductase inhibitors that are active in a in a in human mice under a certain amount, right?
So you're trying to inhibit some.
Activity in the body and so we have these set of business questions and the idea is that our platform should enable you through applications through other mechanisms.
To answer these top 20 business questions.
So to answer these business questions, the the thing you want to ask yourself is what kind of data do you need to answer these questions?
Well, it turns out that a majority of these business questions actually require data from lots of different sources, right?
And we actually had one of our researchers go and do the top ranked business question.
Today we had them go without our software without any platform.
What would you do today?
To answer that question?
And it actually took them three days with five people.

And these are five PhD professionals working really hard to answer this top business question case and a lot of what they did was copy and paste columns in different Excel spreadsheets together, did some munging on the data to get it in a form they could actually analyze, right?
So a lot of that time is spent.
Doing data integration.
So to answer these questions you need, for example, what is the selectivity profile of these inhibitors?
You probably need a database of inhibitors so you go to something like Campbell and it's going to hit a particular protein.
You'll need something from uni prot.
You may need terminological services, so you'll need a data set like you unless you may want information about pathways so you may not be familiar with all these kinds of data, that's OK.
But the point is, is that you have data coming from many different sources.
Public data, so all these over here are public and the ones in.
Kind of lighter blue are private, right?
So we need to integrate across these different sources.
So we did this kind of standard agile work really fast.
Create a platform quickly give it to our clients, they complain, we do it again.
We keep doing it and about a year into the projects we release something.
We got a public release.
We're now on our third public release of this platform and that's being used today, and I think of if you're thinking about developing these kinds of projects.
This kind of agile approach is actually very beneficial.
Even inside a kind of a research project base.
So that's kind of where we're coming from.
We need to integrate a lot of different data sources.
From different public domain data sources for business questions derived from farm industry.
So we created this open fax, a discovery platform and you've already do.
Played our architecture picture so a lot of these data integrations approaches have really a lot of the same themes, right?
So you convert everything to some semantic web technologies.
RDF.
You put them somewhere you provide some sort of indexing mechanisms.

In our case we have to worry a lot about what we called domain specific services, so being able to do things like chemistry search, which it turns out to be very complicated thing to do, and one of our big things.
And this is what Jan from Mendeley was mentioning before.
Is what I would call an API or is an API so providing access to this data in an easy to use fashion for developers and that's been a real success story for us, making it easy for.
I would say a kind of a typical web developer or app developer to be able to work on top of our platform.
So that's all the complicated description.
So what we what we have is we've integrated all these data sources going over main core components of data within drug discovery.
So this is target information.
So this is the kinds of proteins you're trying to target with a particular drug, a chemical compound, and also how these react and pathways.
And we are actually going to introduce in two weeks disease data into that, so you can search from the perspective of disease.
From this perspective of target going across all these data sources in one thing, so inside the platform we have about 14 million entities.
That's described by about 3.5 billion triples, so it's.
I don't know if it's big data anymore.
I mean it's a it's a lot of data, but it's not big data, but it's big data in terms of the variety of data.
Protein datasets is really really different from chemistry datasets, and so integrating those is pretty complicated and I'll give you one example of why it's complicated in a second.
So this is all available.
Our platform is there.
We have this dev dot open facts.org, so if you're one of the techies in the crowd you can go play with this sign up, have API key free to use.
Pound away, see what it is.
If you're interested in this space, we provide all the kind of nice access mechanisms so you get your Jason.
You get XML.
If you like XML, we even give TSV files back.
If you're really into spreadsheets.
So that's the platform in a really simple form.
What I want to talk about now is a couple of the hard things in developing this platform.
So one is.
It's not really about the data per say.

It's often about the service level agreement that you can provide on the data, so one of the things we did in the project is actually tender for a secure hosted environment to host this entire platform, so it's not sitting on some server in a cabinet somewhere.
It's actually at the Amsterdam Internet exchange on a really big machine with the big pipes with 24 by 7 monitoring.
On it, and so.
Thinking about that with security policy's in place and signed agreements about what that security means.
So all that plumbing, all that kind of policy framework around the platform is really important.
So that's one thing we had to deal with.

Another thing that we've heard a lot about during the conference is licensing and what we did was we have different data sources and we wanted to know what is the relationship in particular around open data and open data licenses and what that means to us because I have to say pharma companies are rightly scared of not correctly using data and correctly licensed data.
So all of our data is licensed.
We tendered with John Wilbanks, who was one of the on the team with the Creative Commons.
On the team of Creative Commons to give us a kind of a portfolio and outline of data licensing and how we deal with data licensing.

So to deal with that, we also have provenance everywhere, so we can tell you when we give you an integrated result where it came from and actually what the data source licenses under that we can track back completely.
And this is really important not only from the licensing perspective but also from the trustworthiness expresses we express perspective.
So oftentimes will have is users come back and they say I don't.
I don't think your data is right.
We've got this integrated data.
Your platform must be wrong.
Right, you must be doing something wrong, but we can trace back to the original data source and say look, this is what it is in the original data source.
This is how we got it, so it's a really important part of dealing with this variety of data.
So back to this variety, it's often pretty easy to integrate, but oftentimes it's hard to integrate well.
Right, and this is particularly apparent in this domain.
This comes from an actual system that we've seen out in the wild that does drug discovery, data integration, and if you start typing Gleevec.
So Gleevec is a cancer drug by Novartis, you actually start getting to search results back.
Why?
Because they actually mapped between their datasets based not on string Gleevec, but actually on a compound structure.
And that compound structure was differing across two different datasets.
So according to their integration scheme, those are two different things.
They have two different compounds.
So.
What is gleevec?
What is this actual cancer drug?
It's it's a cancer drug from Novartis.
Well, it's actually.
Chemically, two things.
It's a mad, and if Anet has the salt called mesylate on it, so Gleevec is amount of nib mesylate.
But if you look at different data sources.
That will be registered in different ways in chem.
Spider, which is a database is chemistry.
It's amount amid mesley.
But if you look in Drug Bank, which is a database of all FDA licensed drugs, it's Gleevec is actually a mountain.
They dropped assault.
Right, so are those two the same thing?
Who knows, right?
You have to be a domain specialist.
If we look at pubchem, they actually have both of Madden.
If an, they have a Madam nib mesylate, as well as two different entries.
Are they the same thing or all those three the same thing?
It actually depends, right?
So what we've done is to cater for different precisions on integration.
We.
We have what we call dynamic equality.
So what you can say is.
We have different link sets that says OK, I'm really want to be strict.
I only care about chemistry that has the salt forms correct?
'cause I'm a computational chemist so I can slide my slider, give me only strict integration so you wouldn't connect.
Drugbank and chem.
Spider, but if you're just browsing, why don't you have more relaxed attitude?
I want everything in the world you know about something that looks like a mounted in right or Gleevec, and so you can be.
More relaxed, and so we provide that kind of adaptive link sets as part of the platform.
So those are a couple examples of the things that we've had to consider and developing this platform.
5 minutes cool.
And there's a lot more, and I'm happy to talk to you offline if you want to know more how we developed it.
So we've had this platform for about a year.
One of the drivers was to develop to have apps developed on this platform.
So how are we doing on?
Not so.
This is our hit graph, so we launched at the Royal Society of Chemistry in April 2013 and we have this nice trend line with the Spiker on Christmas.
So we have we have a run rate about 2.5 million hits a month right now, and that's pretty good.
We hope even we want one of those kind of really spiky curves like that, but it's but it's pretty good.
More importantly, we have.
Bunch of different apps that build on top of this platform because it's oftentimes hard to consider what you want to do with all this data, right?
So we have apps ranging from integration with Excel all the way to a PDF readers.
My favorite app is the one on my is the most expensive app I've ever purchased in my life.
It was $25.
It's the molecular mobile molecular data sheet that has integration with this and we didn't even know that this happened.
It was a. SMEs based somewhere else, and they looked at our API and they wanted this information.
They integrated with our API.
So we have a number of different applications built on this.
One is the open fax Explorer and this is kind of cool because it's so boring.
This is actually a interface that you would use from Lundbeck, which is a pharmaceutical company.
What we did was we took their normal chemistry browsing.
Infrastructure interface that they use inside their company.
We ripped out the back end and we put it in open fax right?
So this is what a typical.
Typically you would use inside that pharma company.
This is another cool app.
Called chem bio navigator.
This lets you on your iPad.
You can go to chembionavigator.org, browse chemical space, right?

So if you're talking with somebody about a particular set of chemicals you're interested in, you just have that on your iPad and you can talk together, circle things, do chemistry, structure searching all there.
And that's again using the same API.
One of the big interesting things that came up was that in pharma companies they use a lot of workflow engines.
In particular, one is called pipeline pilot, so we have integration with all these two of these workflow engines and have workflow components.
And we've seen that this has been really effective inside the companies for take.
So one example of this is at Ianson Pharmaceutical.
They've been using this to search.
The public domain data an integrate that with their internal datasets on things like finding compounds that will attack particular protein structures.
So where are we going in the future?
Because we're in this kind of interesting consortium right of pharmaceutical companies, it's both public and private and it's pre competitive.
What it means is that we've created kind of a form for people to come and talk right before.
It's difficult.
For example, for a vendor to go talk to maybe a pharmaceutical company, because in some sense there's kind of a.
A potential sales relationship here.

So within open fax you can essentially have that conversation between, for example, app developers and pharma companies, or you can have a conversation between data providers and pharmaceutical companies or academic researchers and pharmaceutical companies.
And that's really only possible because of the nature of the project itself.
So how are we?
Continue this project.
How are you going to sustain this platform going forward?
How do we pay for for all the maintenance and all the services that I said?
So we've set up the Open Fax Foundation, so this is a nonprofit foundation in the UK.
And here what we have is memberships where corporations or smaller SMS can be members and help sustain this platform.
And by by building community around these memberships, essentially we can sustain the platform for the entire community for our pharma companies, but also for academic research.
And with that I'll take some.
